Cook it

The cooking app that helps easily find recipes and more
Prototype

Overview

Task
Design a user-friendly recipe app, that could be used without a paid account.

Design goals
1. Design a recipe app that will be aesthetically pleasing and easy to navigate.
2. Add the "Search by ingredient" feature.
3. Create branding (design system)

Year
2021 - 2022.

Duration
4 weeks

Tools
Figma
Maze
Miro

Research

User surveys and interviews
From User surveys and interviews I wanted to know more details about users' frustrations when using recipe apps, features they looking for, additional preferences.
To better understand users I interviewed 6 people from different occupations aged 25 to 60. The interviews were done via Zoom using open-ended questions.

60% of users find that the most
appealing feature is search filters

From previous experience with recipe apps, 75% of users didn't like navigation

40% of participants don't want to read recipes without step by step guidance

Main outcomes
- Participants wish to have step-by-step guidance when cooking.
- Easy navigation through the app - is crucial (most of the participants said that they quit using the application if it's overcomplicated).
- When searching for recipes participants don't mind having a cooking time filter.

Competitive analysis
Competitive analysis was a very important part of the research. I wanted to understand my competitor's strains and weaknesses. Using the SWOT method I compared the 4 most popular cooking apps: FoodNetwork, Tasty, Yummly, and SideChef.

Affinity map
After performing research I created an affinity map to help me better brainstorm and analyze all data that I have.

User persona
I tried to create a persona that will represent the target user. This step helped me to identify the main features I wanted to focus on.

SOFI

About

Status - Realtor
Age - 42

Status - Married
Kids - Two

Bio
Sofi is a full-time realtor and mom. She loves to cook but does not always have a lot of time to spend in the kitchen. Sofi always looking for new culinary ideas and inspiration. Her ultimate goal is to lead a healthy lifestyle for the entire family.

Goals
- to spend minimum time at the kitchen
- find easy recipes
- healthy lifestyle

Frustrations
- can't find what to cook
- lack of inspiration
- long articles

Information architecture

User stories
I identified user stories for already existing users and ranked them by priority

was created. I focused on 3 user stories:

Site map

Wireframes

Branding

I feel like branding is one of my favorite stages in the design process. Creating a mood board, helped me to come out with colors, find app's mood and style.

Mood board

Design system

High Fidelity Mockups

At this step of the design process, I added design to the wireframes and also applied some changes to the layout (after 1st round of usability testing I found some crucial mistakes, results from you can find below)

Usability tests

For this project, I've conducted two rounds of usability testing

First Usability test
Before adding design to the wireframes I wanted to test first. Using a low-fidelity prototype I did a mission usability test via Maze. Goal was to examine how users interact with navigation.

One of the tasks was to find the recipe that can be cooked with N number of ingredients. On the heat maps below, we can see that instead of clicking Search most of the participants were choosing Recipe.

Main findings
- The navigation bar is confusing (participants found Recipes and Home pages too similar and got lost when searching for the recipes)
- Search by ingredient button was hard to find right away (again because navigation menu options were too similar to each other)

Solution
- The navigation bar was changed to just 3 options (Home/ Search and Saved recipes)
- Additional "Search by ingredient" was added to the Home page.
- The Home page was combined with the Recipe page.

Second Usability test
After adding changes to the wireframes, I've started the second round of usability testing using Hi-fidelity mockups. Eight participants took part in the second round. The goal was to check how users will interact with updated navigation. Based on data - all participants were able to complete the task flow without any errors.

Final thoughts

This project helped me to improve my UI skills and gave me an opportunity to learn more about usability. Spending extra time conducting two usability tests was crucial, as it helped me to fix some important issues before adding design.
